title: I Cried While Playing League
body:
I am so tired of the toxicity in this sad excuse of a "community." Out of all the games I've played in my life, the people here are the absolute worst. I started playing League a few years ago, but I ended up leaving the game briefly after I began because I was flamed too often for "sucking" or "feeding." I've been back for not even a month, and I've experienced this tenfold. I already want to quit again, and I hate it because I absolutely enjoy the gameplay. I've been told to kill myself, commit suicide, uninstall League, never play said champ again, and endless colorful insults that I wish to not think about.

I've had two or three games (one of which happened today) so far this past month (which is the amount of time I've been back) where the abuse was so bad to the point where I actually cried. I was trying out Syndra today in a non-ranked game, and I was laning against someone who clearly REALLY knew how to play Yasuo (quite aggressively at that). I attempted to play passively and farm under turret. The guy doesn't care and still dives. Ended up dying a few times and then was focused by the enemy jungler and mid laner because I was so far behind. I made it clear as day to my teammates that I was learning the champ. I also explained that I'd practiced the champ in bot games, read guides, and wanted to try her out in PVP. But this didn't stop people from acting like complete jerks. I was bashed so often and so early to the point where I was considering leaving the game, because at that point, I would have rather been reported and banned for leaving the game than be bullied anymore. I didn't discover the mute button until after that game, but that's beside the point.

I do everything I know to do deal with toxicity — report, (now) mute, not adding fuel to the fire, taking breaks, finding other games, or all of those. I don't know how exactly how many players I've reported for bad behavior — maybe ~50 so far. Only 2 have been banned.

I am aggravated. And sick of this. I don't know how else to deal with it, other than what I'm doing now.

Side note: I do not play ranked games.

> she has the same right to play this game as anyone else.

Oh, except people with anger mental disabilities? Or don't you care about those disabilities, only the ones you can sympathize with?

I expect people with disabilities to do in game what they do in public, find ways to take care of themselves so that it isn't a hindrance to them. If that means yelling in your room, do that. If that means hitting ESC instead of Enter, do that.

Plenty of people get overly angry while playing the game, it doesn't mean they have to perform in a way that make the experience worse for others.

But it doesn't mean using mute? There is a restaurant in Tennessee where the staff constantly insult you. Wouldn't make much sense for someone with MDD to go there, would it? 

The simple truth is that you cannot change how other people behave. You cannot make people "be nice". So, if you're not going to take steps to help your own situation, and instead just play the woe is me card, I have no sympathy for you. Just as I have no sympathy for people that complain about being overweight when they don't exercise or diet.

Yes, we should expect people with rage disabilities to control themselves. But, we should also hold people with depressive issues to the same exact standard.

Depression issues is why I think people do need to manage themselves. I have friends that have struggled with thoughts of suicide and have played this game. Do you *really* think it's OK to *ever* tell someone to kill themselves (sometimes there first words out of players mouths, before you know to mute them)?

I expect people to be decent human beings. That shouldn't require anyone to change how they behave, but rather be consistent in how they behave. A person doesn't lose their humanity just because they sit in front of a computer screen.

I have legit never been told to kill myself. I have never seen anyone say that first. And I mute people that probably go on to say it. So I'm honestly confused as to why people keep saying this. Are these players not using mute, and then agitating people to try to bait them to flame them or something? Not too mention, people that tell others to kill themselves are quickly banned by the automated system.

I mean honestly, telling people with anger issues to just "not be a dick" is literally the same exact thing as telling people with depression to "just get over it". There is no difference lol.

> If that means yelling in your room, do that. If that means hitting ESC instead of Enter, do that.

I started out giving ways you can manage the anger. What techniques do you use in public? I bet you can apply them in game.

First, I'd recommend you don't bother telling people you are new to a champion.  While there is nothing wrong with that, most people won't really mind that and it won't dissuade those who want to be jerks.
--------------------
Second, you should know that the notification that a player you have reported has been punished will only occur if your report was the final one to trigger the punishment.  If they were punished the game after the one they played with you due to another report, you won't get that notification.

In addition, the system generally looks for patterns of behaviour.  They will likely not be punished if that were a sole or very rare occurrence, but reports will accumulate until they are punished if they continue.
----------------------
Third, standard procedure when dealing with harassment is generally:

1. Mute (to spare yourself)
2. Report (to spare others)
3. Move on

Their opinion shouldn't really matter to you; they are just anonymous players you were in a single game with and will likely never see again.
-----------------------
Fourth, you have to develop a thicker skin.  

While I am aware that this may sound somewhat callous, you will encounter those types of players in almost any game you play.  The combination of anonymity and reliance on allies in online games tends to bring out the worst in some people.

Personally, I tend to derive amusement from the stupidity of ragers.  Finding amusement at their impotent rage is how I shield myself from toxic players and prevent them from tilting me.

Yeah, this community can really suck sometimes. You need to find some good people to play with. The game is far more enjoyable if you are playing with some friends. Send me a friend invite, and we can play sometimes!

People always talk about the "community" being toxic, but am I the only one who think it is the mechanics of this game that kindle toxic behavior? Snowballing for example, or the fact that last hitting monsters and champions gives you a big extra bonus (a feature traditionally abused by griefers in MMOs and hence uncommon in MMOs today), also the concept of 'meta' and its encouragement or enforcement by the developer which leads to people feeling justified to attack others for not playing the game "right" (because there is perceived to be a "right" way that people are supposed to play, even if every individual has a different idea about what exactly that is). This game is filled with mechanics that may as well have been designed to frustrate people and make them rage.

Obviously the game is also a lot of fun in various ways, otherwise people wouldn't play it. But those dynamics (frustrating + genuinely fun) are a toxic combo in themselves, because people get doubly raged when they are trying to have fun and expecting fun and then find their quest for fun frustrated and unsuccessful.

I just don't buy that somehow this game is a magnet for bad apples. Mechanics within the game itself are what drives the pervasive toxicity.

Imagine if champions and teams didn't snowball hard, for example. Would that make pro matches more or less interesting? I'm pretty sure it would make them more interesting, because there would be a lot more opportunities for players to outplay each other and show what they are really capable of, rather than who can get ahead first and then they have a huge advantage with every exchange being unequal and requiring a big mistake for someone to lose once they are ahead. Because of the snowball factor, mistakes in LoL have a huge consequence, which creates an uptight, passive-aggressive style of play and basically encourages negative emotions all around.

There's one piece about your situation I don't understand: mute.  If you are getting flamed because you're playing poorly, why not mute?  Also, I am assuming you are younger since if getting flamed in an online video game is enough to break you and make you cry, I have some bad news for you about real life.  I would almost suggest that you actually keep getting exposed to this kind of abuse because hopefully it will toughen you up.

Why?  Because life.  Lifes.  Not.  Fair.  Read that again, make it your mantra, and embrace it.  Your entire life you will be put into situations where you will be given the short stick, or get blamed for something, or somebody is going to be a dick.  And guess what?  Crying when exposed to these things isn't a reaction that is going to help you come out on top.  

I'm not saying that the people who acted like this in game are right; in fact, quite the opposite.  I don't believe that anybody should have to be exposed to this type of stuff.  But again, Riot gives you a way of dealing with it with a mute button.  Stop looking for places where you can be cared about and given a "safe space" and start developing resiliency and the ability to solve your own problems.  The latter will result in a much more positive outcome for you, both in League and in general.
